website_summaries.verdict: The Acer C720 adds an Intel Core i3 processor to the company's Chromebook lineup. Chrome OS power users who rely on dozens of extensions and plugins should feel the benefit, but they'll pay.
pros: 4GB of memory and a Intel Core i3 CPU

customer_reviews.title: Awesome browser
customer_reviews.text: I was a little skeptical at first, never having used a Chromebook before, but I have found it to be a superior browsing experience. Makes sense, since this is pretty much all it does. I've installed a few Chrome apps and add-ons and everything works flawlessly. I'm really glad I sprang for the fastest C720 Acer offers. It's worth it. Take the time to make sure you're getting the right model, it can be tricky since the model is the same for quite a few different versions of this unit, and vendors are not always clear about which one they are offering.
customer_reviews.author: Roland Barker

customer_reviews.title: Great for running Ubuntu
customer_reviews.text: Great little device; faster than my much more expensive Sony Vaio (from 2010, admittedly). I'm running Linux Ubuntu 14.04 alongside Chrome OS on it without a hiccup. For any developers out there: I have no problem developing a fairly sized Django Python project on it, with a MySQL db in the background. Another thing that is noteworthy is that the keyboard is fairly well spaced and reminds a bit of the Macbook's keyboard. The keys feel a bit cheap, but well, this is not a Macbook obviously. The price seems hard to beat.
customer_reviews.author: Stijn Heymans

customer_reviews.title: You won't find better for the price
customer_reviews.text: Only two, minor complaints - there's no delete key on the keyboard, or right-click function built into the trackpad (you have to use Alt with clicking or Backpace to do these). That said, this is the industry standard for Chromebooks right now - and is powerful enough that I'm actually able to use it as my primary computer. You won't find better for the price. Battery life is incredible, and given how lightweight the operating system is, combined with the SSD, the processor feels much snappier than a similar-specced computer would with another OS. Well worth it.
customer_reviews.author: Jabber

customer_reviews.title: Fast chromebook with poor display, keyboard and build.
customer_reviews.text: The Core i3 processor in this Acer chromebook makes it a great user experience. The notebook is the right size. The screen leaves something to be desired, specially for off-angle viewing. And the build quality is indicative of the price point. The keyboard is pretty abysmal. I would really like a chromebook that doesn't compromise on build quality, specially the keyboard. Add to that a quality ~11" touchscreen display. Put a Core i3 or one of the new Core M processors in there along with 4GB or 8GB of memory. And you have a chromebook that you will want to use. The Lenovo Thinkpad Yoga Chromebook 11e delivers on most of this I think - everything but the processor.
customer_reviews.author: Maverick

customer_reviews.title: great Linux laptop
customer_reviews.text: Worth every penny as a Linux laptop. Decent processor (i3), RAM (4GB), FAST SSD. I replaced ChromeOS with Linux (XUbuntu with XFCE) and now use it as my primary developer workstation with external keyboard and mouse and monitor. Works great! I even watch videos on it without any problems. Only two gripes. Screen resolution is too low, but that's understandable given the small size. And the other is the keyboard layout. The ChromeBook keyboard layout is not as good as the standard PC keyboard layout. Very hard to type fast. Also, battery life I get is about 6 hours, not 8 hours.
customer_reviews.author: Tiger128

customer_reviews.title: Still the best value in an 11" chromebook, in my opinion.
customer_reviews.text: Still the best value in an 11" chromebook, in my opinion. Core i3, 32gb SSD and 4gb ram. Build quality feels a bit cheap, but I've yet to have one crap out on me. This is my second, with the first one 2 years old and still working great.... just needed the 4gb ram. (Do NOT get a C720 with less than 4GB of ram... you'll regret it if you keep more than a few tabs open at once.) I have never had anything break on my 2 year old one, and it's banged around all over the country with me.

customer_reviews.title: No Complaints Whatsoever
customer_reviews.text: I love it. I am using it as I am typing this. Before you buy it however, I would do research on whether or not you want a Chromebook (assuming you didn't already). The screen isn't the best (but I don't need it to be) and with that said, the viewing angles are rather bad. Overall though, if you want to use it for work, the battery life is great and the processor can handle quite a bit. I can have 9 or so tabs open at once and experience no problems. Great for what I use it for.

customer_reviews.title: Acer C720 Chromebook Black Screen & No Fix???
customer_reviews.text: Worked good for a while and then just went black screen? The screen is black, no noise, you can charge it to the blue LED but it will not turn on and you cannot do any type of reset. I reviewed several online forums and this seems to be a reoccurring/typical problem with Acer products. Everyone pretty much gives the same comment; Acer cannot fix the problem and it's quicker and cheaper to just buy another Chromebook. So I'm out $300.00 on this Chromebook and had to purchase another one for about the same amount. Unless you have unlimited funds, I would suggest another manufacturer besides Acer. Cheaply built and it's been proven.

customer_reviews.title: Amazing with one major problem
customer_reviews.text: This chromebook is amazing except for one problem. It randomly shuts off during use. I will be watching a video or be in the middle of writing an email, and the computer turns off for no reason. Aside from that major problem, the computer is very fast and more than I expected. I would give it five stars if it did not randomly shut off during use. I am still trying to figure out if there is a way to solve the problem, otherwise I may send it back in.

customer_reviews.text: i ended up going with an HP Chromebook 11 over this Acer. the Acer was much faster, especially loading heavier pages like photos.google.com. something like rendering Google Maps as you zoom in/out is much faster on this Chromebook. if performance is what you're after then this Chromebook is for you. the reasons i chose the HP instead are 100% aesthetic. this Acer feels cheap, the power cord is big and bulky.. it just has no sexiness to the design. but loads pages really fast.

customer_reviews.title: restricted use with multiple tabs open
customer_reviews.text: Best used delicately as a guest or an account with no bookmarks and few apps. Inconvenient for a basic pc user that likes to browse over ten tabs and keep all her bookmarks; chromebooks won't allow that without exchanging battery life and all the memory. New user- 5 tabs open, 1 app: memory usage is at half way and will progressively increase. Main user with all my bookmarks and 10 apps: exchanges five hours of battery life or with ten tabs open, pc will easily heat up and whir; memory usage availability: a consistent 5%-1% and battery life of 2-3 hours.

customer_reviews.title: Kryptonite for creativity and freedom
customer_reviews.text: Extremely limited system, with appealing but arbitrarily shackled specs. If you're fond of walled gardens, go for it. It's probably most fit for obedient children, Americans ... or North Koreans. But of course, most hardware is moving in this direction and soon nothing will offer any measure of freedom, despite the inherent capabilities of modern hardware. These things should be rented rather than sold - it would be more honest. My advice: Find a real computer while they last, and find it somewhere other than Amazon!
